importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Susan Stamberg began hosting 'All Things Considered' in 1972, becoming the first woman to host a national news program, which broke gender norms in broadcast journalism.

Stamberg hosted a two-hour radio call-in program with President Jimmy Carter from the Oval Office in 1979, marking a significant moment in public engagement between a national news broadcaster and a U.S. President.
She joined NPR in the early 1970s when it was forming as a network, contributing to its early development and cultural influence in American media.
Stamberg received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020, recognizing her impact on both media and cultural industries.
She passed away on October 16, 2025, at age 87, prompting national media attention and honoring her legacy in public broadcasting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 1970s were critical for the founding and development of NPR, and Stamberg's early work helped shape its identity, especially by pioneering gender-inclusive broadcasting styles.
Her 1979 Oval Office call-in with President Carter marked a milestone in public diplomacy and citizen engagement through media.
Her star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020 affirmed her lasting influence on both journalism and popular culture.

keyTakeAways: Susan Stamberg was the first woman to host a national news program on American radio, breaking gender barriers in broadcast journalism.
She co-founded the concept of 'founding mothers' in NPR, highlighting women's roles in shaping public media.
She hosted 'All Things Considered' for 14 years and later contributed to 'Weekend Edition Sunday' by launching the Sunday puzzle feature with Will Shortz.
Stamberg interviewed prominent public figures such as Nancy Reagan, Rosa Parks, and James Baldwin, showcasing her ability to uncover compelling stories.
Her conversational, natural style contrasted with the formal, actor-like delivery of other women broadcasters at the time, helping define a new standard for radio journalism.
She hosted a historic live call-in program with President Jimmy Carter in 1979, giving citizens direct access to the Oval Office.
She was inducted into the National Radio Hall of Fame and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020, recognizing her broad cultural and media impact.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Susan Stamberg, a pioneering female broadcaster and one of the founding figures of National Public Radio (NPR), died at age 87. As the first woman to host a national news program on radio, she helped redefine broadcast journalism by adopting a natural, conversational style that contrasted with the formal, actor-like delivery of her female peers. She hosted 'All Things Considered' for 14 years and later contributed to 'Weekend Edition Sunday,' where she launched a Sunday puzzle feature with Will Shortz. She also hosted a historic call-in program with President Jimmy Carter in 1979 and interviewed major cultural and political figures including Rosa Parks and James Baldwin. Stamberg is credited with coining the term 'founding mothers' to describe women instrumental in launching NPR, alongside Cokie Roberts, Nina Totenberg, and Linda Wertheimer. Recognized for her intelligence, empathy, and storytelling, she was inducted into the National Radio Hall of Fame and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2020, underscoring her broad cultural and media impact.
title: Susan Stamberg, first woman to host a national news program, dies at age 87
